Class ConstituencyTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • ConstituencyTree

  • public class ConstituencyTree
extends java.lang.Object
    Author:
    Christine Bocionek (initial version), Katja KÃ¶nig (computeTerminalCandidates, adjustments to getArgumentNode for conjunction normalization) An instance of the class ConstituencyTree represents the constituent structure of a sentence. It consists of a Nonterminal root node, Nonterminal and Terminal nodes and a HashMap transitions where a parent node is a key and the value is a list of child nodes (representing the parent-child relationship between nodes in a tree). The list of child nodes is organized such that the leftmost child node is the first item in the list and the rightmost child node is the last. An instance of ConstituencyTree is built from an instance of the Salsa Java API class Graph. Uses the Salsa Java API classes listed below (http://www.coli.uni-saarland.de/projects/salsa/page.php?id=software) to build the tree:
    See Also:
    Graph, Nonterminal, Terminal, Edge, Id

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ConstituencyTree(Graph graph)
      Given a Graph object from the Salsa API representing the constituency structure of a sentence, extract its hierarchy to create a tree structure.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConstituencyTree

        public ConstituencyTree(Graph graph)
        Given a Graph object from the Salsa API representing the constituency structure of a sentence, extract its hierarchy to create a tree structure. The extraction is performed by the method extractConstituencyTree(Graph graph).
        Parameters:
        graph - The Graph object from which the tree is constructed.

        Returns:
        The Graph object from which the ConstituencyTree was created.

      • getRoot

        public Nonterminal getRoot()
        Returns:
        The Nonterminal root node of the ConstituencyTree.

      • getTrueRoot

        public Nonterminal getTrueRoot()
        The root of most parse trees is a node with category "PSEUDO". This method tries to find the node that actually represents the parsed sentence and usually has the category "S".
        Returns:
        The true root node if it can be detected. Else, getRoot()

      • getTerminals

        public java.util.ArrayList<Terminal> getTerminals()
        Returns:
        An ArrayList of all Terminal nodes of the ConstituencyTree.

      • getNonterminals

        public java.util.ArrayList<Nonterminal> getNonterminals()
        Returns:
        An ArrayList of all Nonterminal nodes of the ConstituencyTree.

      • getTransitions

        public java.util.HashMap<Nonterminal,java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object>> getTransitions()
        Returns:
        A HashMap representing the edges between nodes in the ConstituencyTree. A key is a Nonterminal parent node and its value is an ArrayList of child nodes. A child node can be either a Nonterminal or a Terminal node.

      • hasChildren

        public boolean hasChildren(Nonterminal node)
        Checks whether a given Nonterminal node has child nodes.
        Parameters:
        node - A Nonterminal node of the ConstituencyTree.
        Returns:
        "True" if the given Nonterminal node has child nodes, "False" if it does not.

      • getChildren

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object> getChildren(Nonterminal node)
        Parameters:
        node - A Nonterminal node of the ConstituencyTree.
        Returns:
        An ArrayList of child nodes of the given Nonterminal node. The return value is "null" if the Nonterminal node does not have child nodes.

      • hasParent

        public boolean hasParent(java.lang.Object node)
        Checks whether a given Nonterminal or Terminal node has a parent node.
        Parameters:
        node - A Nonterminal or Terminal node.
        Returns:
        "True" if the given node has a Nonterminal parent node, "False" if it does not. In the latter case, the given node is the root node.

      • getParent

        public Nonterminal getParent(java.lang.Object node)
        Parameters:
        node - A Nonterminal or Terminal node.
        Returns:
        The Nonterminal parent node of the given node. If the given node is the root node, "null" will be returned.

      • isTerminal

        public boolean isTerminal(java.lang.String word)
        Parameters:
        word - A String representing a word.
        Returns:
        "True" if the given word is part of the sentence which the ConstituencyTree represents, "False" if it is not.

      • getTerminal

        public Terminal getTerminal(WordObj word)
        Parameters:
        word - A WordObj containing a word as a String and additional information associated with it.
        Returns:
        "True" if the word associated with the given WordObj is part of the sentence which the ConstituencyTree represents. Additionally, the given WordObj's position in the sentence which it was retrieved from has to be identical to the position of the word in the sentence which the ConstituencyTree represents. If one or both of these conditions does not hold, "False" is returned.

      • dominates

        public boolean dominates(Nonterminal nonterminal,
                Terminal terminal)
        Checks whether a given Nonterminal node dominates a given Terminal node, i.e. whether it is an ancestor of that node. Iterates over all nodes that are reachable from the given Nonterminal node and checks whether one of them is the given Terminal node.
        Parameters:
        nonterminal - A Nonterminal node.
        terminal - A Terminal node.
        Returns:
        "True" if the given Nonterminal node dominates the given Terminal node, "False" if it does not.

      • addTransition

        public void addTransition(Nonterminal parent,
                 java.lang.Object child)
        Given a Nonterminal parent node and a Nonterminal or Terminal child node, create a transition in the tree between them. Helper function of the method extractConstituencyTree(Graph graph).
        Parameters:
        parent - The Nonterminal parent node of the transition.
        child - The Nonterminal or Terminal child node of the transition.

      • extractConstituencyTree

        public void extractConstituencyTree(Graph graph)
        Given a Graph object from the Salsa API, build the ConstituencyTree. Starting from the root, the tree is created tier by tier. Nodes are identified by the Id assigned by the Salsa API.
        Parameters:
        graph - The Graph object as built by the Salsa API.

      • descendTree

        public java.lang.Object descendTree(Nonterminal nonterminal,
                           Terminal terminal,
                           int lenPath)
        Given a Nonterminal node and a Terminal node, the ConstituencyTree will be descended for a given path length starting from the Nonterminal node towards the Terminal node.
        Parameters:
        nonterminal - The Nonterminal node from which the descent starts.
        terminal - The Terminal node towards which the descent is directed.
        lenPath - The distance of the target node from the given Nonterminal node.
        Returns:
        The Nonterminal or Terminal node which is separated from the given Nonterminal node by a given path length and either dominates the given Terminal node or is the node itself.

      • getArgumentString

        public java.lang.String getArgumentString(WordObj predicate,
                                 WordObj argument)
        Given an argument and a predicate in a ConstituencyTree, we want to return the String which corresponds to the phrase which a) either dominates the argument node or is the argument node b) is directly dominated by the node which dominates both the predicate and the argument node Example: [ S [ NP [ DET The] [ N gardener] [ VP [V likes ] [ NP [ PN his ] [ N flowers ] ] ] ] ] Given that "likes" is the predicate and "gardener" is the argument, this function will first find the lowest node in the tree which dominates both the predicate and argument node (here: S: "The gardener likes his flowers"). From this node, the function will then descend the tree for a path length of 1 in the direction of the argument. The node retrieved in this way is our target node. The string corresponding to this node will be returned.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate represented by a WordObj.
        argument - The argument represented by a WordObj.
        Returns:
        The String corresponding to the phrase whose node is dominated directly by the lowest node in the tree dominating both the predicate and the argument node.

      • getArgumentNode

        public java.lang.Object getArgumentNode(WordObj predicate,
                               WordObj argument,
                               DependencyGraph depGraph)
        Given an argument and a predicate in a ConstituencyTree, we want to return a node which a) either dominates the argument node or is the argument node b) is directly dominated by the node which dominates both the predicate and the argument node Example: [ S [ NP [ DET The] [ N gardener] [ VP [V likes ] [ NP [ PN his ] [ N flowers ] ] ] ] ] Given that "likes" is the predicate and "gardener" is the argument, this function will first find the lowest node in the tree which dominates both the predicate and argument node (here: S: "The gardener likes his flowers"). From this node, the function will then descend the tree for a path length of 1 in the direction of the argument. The node retrieved in this way is our target node. If 'depGraph' is not null the returned node may violate point a) and b). This case occurs whenever the opinion source is searched. For cases such as sentences containing conjunctions of verbs, predicative and attributive adjectives the "dominates"-relation is not always appropriate. Consider the following example: - Sentence: "The gardener likes and loves this flowers." - Constituency tree: [ S [ VP [ NP [ DET The ] [ N gardener ] ] [ V likes ] ] [ CON and ] [ VP [ V loves ] [ NP [ PN his] [ N flowers ] ] ] ] Opinion source for "loves" should be "The gardener" but with the original implementation it was "The gardener likes" (i.e. 'VP' node instead of the 'NP' node was returned). As only the 'S' dominates the predicate 'loves' and the argument 'gardener' the implementation chose the 'VP' node since it is direct child node of 'S' (path length 1). Obviously this not desired. The improved implementation follows the constructed path (S, VP, NP, N, gardener) as long as the corresponding subtree contains at least one terminal with the same POS-tag as the predicate (in steps of size 1). Once no such terminal node is found the current node on the path is returned. - S, VP, NP, N, gardener: 'likes' is part of the subtree of S - VP, NP, N, gardener: 'likes' is part of the subtree of VP - NP, N, gardener: 'likes' is no longer part of any subtree As there is no other "candidate" besides 'likes' the search is finished.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate represented by a WordObj.
        argument - The argument represented by a WordObj.
        depGraph - Graph used to retrieve the word list.
        Returns:
        The node which is dominated directly by the lowest node in the tree dominating both the predicate and the argument node.

      • getArgumentNodeMWE

        public java.lang.Object getArgumentNodeMWE(WordObj predicate,
                                  WordObj argument,
                                  java.util.List<WordObj> allPredicateTokens)
        This method is for the extraction of phrases for MWE-predicates Given an argument and an MWE-predicate in a ConstituencyTree, we want to return a node which a) either dominates the argument node or is the argument node b) is dominated by the node which dominates both the MWE-predicate and argument node c) the node must NOT dominate any token of the MWE-predicate
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate represented by a WordObj.
        argument - The argument represented by a WordObj.
        depGraph - Graph used to retrieve the word list.
        allPredicateTokens - All tokens part of the MWE-predicate represented by by a List.
        Returns:
        The node which is dominated directly by the lowest node in the tree dominating both the predicate and the argument node.

      • getPhraseAsString

        public java.lang.String getPhraseAsString(Nonterminal nonterminal)
        Given a Nonterminal node, return the String over which the corresponding phrase spans. E.g. for the sentence "The talented musician played a concert last night", for the Nonterminal node corresponding to the noun phrase "The talented musician", exactly this String will be returned.
        Parameters:
        nonterminal - The Nonterminal node for which the corresponding String is returned.
        Returns:
        The String corresponding to the phrase of the Nonterminal node.
